caseTitle: PETER ANKOMAH V CITY INVESTMENT COMPANY
summary: In Peter Ankomah v City Investment Company Limited, the Supreme Court of Ghana addressed whether damages for loss of use of seized property constitute general or special damages in a detinue claim. The plaintiff's property— a car and refrigerator—was wrongfully seized during execution of a judgment against his wife. The High Court awarded damages for loss of use and replacement value, but the Court of Appeal recharacterized loss of use as special damages requiring strict proof, awarding only nominal damages. The Supreme Court upheld that detinue allows recovery of the chattel or its value plus damages for detention, but emphasized that loss of use is recoverable only where actual damage to the chattel is proven, aligning with English tort law precedents. Since no damage was shown, the plaintiff was not entitled to loss of use damages. The Court affirmed the replacement value awards, noting the trial judge's discretion in assessing reasonable figures despite exaggerated claims.
citations: Halsbury’s Laws of England (5th Ed., 1975) vol 12 para 1416
Salmond and Heuston on the Law of Torts (19th Ed.)
M.A. Jones, Textbook on Torts (8th Ed.)
rationaleHighlights: Damages for loss of use are not recoverable in detinue without proof of actual damage to the chattel.
Loss of use claims require strict proof as special damages when not arising from physical damage.
General damages for loss of use apply only where the chattel is damaged and used for private or commercial purposes.
The trial court properly awarded replacement value despite inflated claims, within judicial discretion.
The Court of Appeal correctly limited recovery to nominal damages due to failure to prove special damages.
